APPLIED CATALYSIS A: GENERAL ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 140 (1996) 17-28 The role of MgO in methane combustion on palladium catalysts Caixia Qi *, Lidun An, Hongli Wang Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, People's Republic of China Received 8 August 1995; revised 15 November 1995; accepted 8 December 1995 Abstract Palladium catalysts supported by T-A1203 and MgO/y-A1203 composites were prepared by conventional impregnation and double impregnation. Methane combustion and methane pulse reactions were tested on the supports and catalysts. It was found that composites of MgO/y-A120s not only had a certain catalytic effect but also modified the activity of the supported palladium catalysts. The function of MgO changed with its amount in the composite and the valence state of palladium. Lattice oxygen in the composite was found to take part in the oxidative reaction and considered as a major factor in influencing the activity of catalysts. The structure and physico- chemical properties of the composite supports were also a possible affecting factor. XRD results and the specific surface area of the supports after high temperature calcination show that introduction of MgO into y-AI203 can enhance the thermal stability of the support to some extent. Keywords: Methane combustion; Palladium; Composite MgO/y-AlzO3; Magnesium oxide 1. Introduction It is well known that MgO possesses typical basic properties and unique reducing properties [1,2]. There are electron donor centers on its surface. These centers are important for methane cracking. As a result, MgO is usually used in the catalysts for methane oxidation coupling [3,4]. During the reaction, radicals formed by the abstraction of one hydrogen atom from methane can also form carbon oxide and carbon dioxide by a branching chain reaction [5,6]. Magnus et al. [7] reported the oxidation of methane over MgO obtained by decomposition * Corresponding author. Fax: ( + 86-931) 8417088. 0926-860X/96/$15.00 1996 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PII S0926-860X(96)000 13-0 18 C. Qi et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 140 (1996) 17 28 of Mg(OH)2, and showed MgO had a significant catalytic effect on the combustion of methane, but the effect was not as strong as with the noble metals. Palladium catalysts are most effective for methane combustion. Sintering at high temperature is one of the problems exhibited by supported palladium catalysts. Magnesium oxide has a melting point of 2850 and a high thermal stability. So the combination of palladium as the active component with MgO as a promoter would be interesting. Matsuura et al. [8] reported methane combus- tion over Pd supported single-crystal MgO. When calcined at 1200, the catalyst maintained 62 m2/g after 4 h and 44 m2/g after 1200 h, it exhibited high activity after this calcination. In recent years, the study of special properties of the composite oxides has aroused great attention [9-11 ]. However, nearly no study on composite MgO/T-A1203 as a support of palladium catalysts for methane combustion has been reported. In our previous work [12], a series of MgO/T-A1203 with different MgO content was prepared and studied for exploring the effect of MgO on the structure and properties of T-A1203. The monolayer dispersion threshold for MgO deposited on alumina is ca. 5 wt.% MgO. When MgO loading is higher than this threshold, the properties of crystalline magnesium oxide will be obvious. In the present study, 0.2 and 5 wt.% MgO/T-AI203 were used as supports to investigate the effect of MgO in a composite on the catalytic performance of supported palladium catalysts for methane combustion. 2. Experimental 2.1. Sample preparation T-A1203, 0.2 and 5 wt.% MgO/T-AI203 as supports were prepared as described elsewhere [12]. Conventional impregnation (CI) and double impregnation (DI) methods were used in preparing palladium catalysts from palladium nitrate. In the latter EDTA was used as chelating agent anchored on the support to chelate noble metal ions (e.g. pd2+). Thermal treatment and reduction conditions of CI and DI catalysts were as described in Ref. [12]. The palladium loading in these samples was ca. 1.95 wt.%. 2.2. Thermal stability of supports The supports mentioned above were heated respectively at 800 and 1000 for 3 h. Then their specific surface areas were measured by the simple BET method (N2 adsorption) and XRD spectra were obtained with a D/MAXRB 12KWX powder diffractometer. C. Qi et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 140 (1996) 17-28 19 2.3. Methane pulse reaction The supports and catalysts mentioned above were tested for methane pulse reaction in a quartz reactor with 1%CH4 + He as reaction gas for the composites and pure methane for the palladium catalysts, as well as He as a carrying gas. For all samples, 300, 350 and 400 were selected as reaction tempera- tures. At first, the sample temperature was raised to 300 from room tempera- ture (10/min) and sampling several pulses, then to 350 and several pulses again, then to 400 in the same way. Products were detected by a Finnigan MAT 700 ion trap detector equipped with a data acquisition system. 2.4. Catalyst testing The activity of the catalysts was tested for the combustion of methane in a flow reactor operating at atmospheric pressure with a 1% methane/oxygen and nitrogen mixture (CH4 : 02 : N2 = 1:4 : 95). The sample (270-320 mg) was placed in a 7 mm i.d. quartz tube and heated to the required temperature. The reaction mixture at a flow rate of 20 ml/min was passed downstream through the catalyst and the products were analyzed on a SC-8 gas chromatograph with a thermal conductivity detector. Methane conversion (x) was calculated based on the following equation: x(%) = (1 -A/Ao) 100, where A is the intensity of the GC peak for methane after reaction, and A0 is its intensity before reaction. 3. The temperature ranges from the start of the reaction to the complete conversion of methane are listed in Table 2. In addition, no C2-hydrocarbon was detected during reaction. By careful comparison, the following observations can be drawn. (1) When active phase and support are the same, the activity of the CI catalyst is higher than that of the corresponding DI one. This is consistent with the result of the CI catalyst having a larger particle size than the DI one [12]. (2) When support and preparation method are the same, overall, PdO is more active than Pd. However, the difference in activity between PdO and Pd gradually decreases with increasing MgO content in the catalyst system. It seems that MgO can reduce the activity of PdO phase to some extent. (3) Whether CI or DI catalysts, when the active phase is Pd, variation in the activity follows the order: 0.2%MgO/y-A1203 > 5%MgO/T-AI203 > T- A1203. Based on these facts, we can conclude that MgO in composite supports can modify the catalytic activity of palladium. This effect changed with the amount of MgO in the composite and the initial valence state of palladium in the supported catalyst. Under oxygen-rich atmosphere, atomic Pd was oxidized during methane oxidation [14-16]. The same result was also obtained in our experiment. However, the effect of MgO on the activities of the supported Pd and PdO catalysts is different. Perhaps it is related to the mechanism of methane oxidation on palladium and the interaction model between MgO with atomic or ionic palladium as well as the Pd-O bonding strength of surface PdO and bulk PdO. 3.4. Catalytic activity of the support In order to explore the contribution of the support to methane combustion, the three supports used in this study were also tested for methane combustion under the same conditions as with the palladium catalysts. Nearly no activity was observed for T-A1203, whereas 0.2%MgO/T-A1203 and 5%MgO/T-A1203 exhibited a certain catalytic effect as showed in Fig. 2. In addition, no C2-hydrocarbon was detected at < 600. In comparison with the palladium catalysts, the activity of the pure supports is certainly much lower. It is worth mentioning that 0.2%MgO/T-A1203 is more active than 5%MgO/T-AI20> This is consistent with the activity result corresponding to palladium catalysts. Combining their isoelectric point (IEP) values and the IR spectra of their adsorptive EDTA [17], it is sure that these two supports exhibit a different surface acidity and structure. Perhaps this is the cause of the higher activity of 0.2%MgO/y-A1203 than that of 5%MgO/y-A1203 and the same order for the corresponding palladium samples. This problem will be further researched in our laboratory. 3.5. Methane pulse reaction It is known that MgO possesses active lattice oxygen. Arai et al. [18] reported that the lattice oxygens of LaMnO3 took part in methane oxidation. Yu et al. [19] pointed out lattice oxygen was the major oxygen species accelerating methane deep oxidation. For the samples containing MgO used in this study, if lattice oxygens do exist, what role do they play during methane combustion? In order to solve these problems, the methane pulse reaction was performed on the composites and corresponding palladium catalysts. 3.6. MgO / y-Al203 supports At first pure methane was used as reaction gas. Nearly no carbon oxides were detected except C2-hydrocarbon at 400 for 5%MgO/y-A1203. Perhaps the concentration of methane was too high, thus a I%CH4 + He mixture was later used as reaction feed. Similar results were obtained at 300, 350 and 400 this time. Little CO2 was detected. The amount of CO2 at these three tempera- tures was basically the same. The same experiment was done on 0.2%MgO/y-A1203 and a similar result was obtained. The formation of little CO2 illustrates that lattice oxygens in the MgO/y- A1203 composite take part in the oxidation of methane, but not active. The methane coupling reaction is dominant in the absence of gaseous oxygen. 3.7. Pure MgO has been proven to be an active catalyst for activating methane even at low temperature [20,21]. When methane is adsorbed on MgO, heterolytic adsorption occurred by electron transfer and carbanion was produced [22,23]. This demon- strated the reducing properties of MgO and the lattice oxygen was considered as a possible source of electron donors [1]. On the other hand, lattice oxygen in MgO possesses oxidizing properties. Chen [24] et al. noted that lattice oxygen was capable of reacting with methane above 200 to form formate and carbonate species. It is therefore proposed that methane activation by lattice oxygen of MgO proceeds via the following scheme: CH4 [0-2] HCOO- or CO2+3 -----) CO2" Perhaps MgO/y-A1203 composite oxides also possess the amphibious prop- erties of reducing and oxidizing. In the case of the methane pulse reaction, they showed mainly the reducing properties due to the formation of much C2-hydro- carbons. When they were used as supports of palladium catalysts, whether Pd or PdO phase, much CO2 was formed in the absence of gaseous oxygen from Table 3. However, as for the palladium catalysts with different states, the contribution of lattice oxygen to methane oxidation is different. The following inference may explain these results. Atomic palladium as a electron donor is stronger than lattice oxygen. When palladium deposits on MgO or a support containing MgO (e.g. MgO/y-Al203 composite), the cracking of methane on palladium is easier and dominating. In this case lattice oxygen and adsorptive oxygen on the surface of the composite act as oxidizers for oxidizing carbanion into carbon dioxide. When methane adsorbs on a PdO/composite, it is possible that electron transfer takes place from lattice oxygen in MgO to Pdz+ and then to methane. The CH3 fragments formed may be oxidized into CO2 by surface oxygen from PdO. Here the lattice oxygens in the composite demonstrate their reducing properties and the ability of oxidation to methane is suppressed. C. Therefore, under the specific reaction conditions, the role of lattice oxygen in the composites may be the same as in the pulse reaction. In order to clarify this point and the inference above, more experimental data are needed. 4. Conclusion Addition of MgO into T-A1203 can enhance the thermal stability of T-A1203 to some extent. Composites of MgO/T-A1203 have a certain catalytic effect on methane combustion. At the same time they can modify the catalytic performance of palladium catalysts. The effect changed with the amount of MgO in the composite and the valence state of palladium. Composite supports with different MgO content exhibited a certain difference in physico-chemical properties and structure. This is a possible factor in influencing the performance of palladium catalysts. The activity of atomic Pd catalysts was improved due to addition of MgO. The enhancing activity was attributed to the active lattice oxygen of the support. However, this improvement was suppressed in supported PdO catalysts. It was found that composites of MgO γ-Al2O3 not only had a certain catalytic effect but also modified the activity of the supported palladium catalysts. The function of MgO changed with its amount in the composite and the valence state of palladium. Lattice oxygen in the composite was found to take part in the oxidative reaction and considered as a major factor in influencing the activity of catalysts. The structure and physicochemical properties of the composite supports were also a possible affecting factor. XRD results and the specific surface area of the supports after high temperature calcination show that introduction of MgO into γ-Al2O3 can enhance the thermal stability of the support to some extent.
